note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter two Serving-men, Peter and Anthony.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.l: _I Would we were remov'd from this Town, Anthony
That we might taſte ſome quiet: for mine owne part,
I'me almoſt melted with continuall trotting
After enquities, dreames, and revelations,
Of who knowes, whom or where? ſerve wenching ſol|diers,
That know no other Paradice but Plackets:
Ile ſerve a Prieſt in Lent, firſt and eate Bell-ropes.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Thou art the froward'ſt foole —

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Why good tame Anthony?
Tell me but this: to what end came we hither?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: To wait upon our Maſters.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: But how Anthony?
Anſwer me that; reſolve me there good Anthony?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: To ſerve their uſes.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Shew your uſes Anthony.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: To be imploy'd in any thing.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: No Anthony,
Not any thing I take it; nor that thing
We travell to diſcover, like new Iſlands;
A ſalt itch ſerve ſuch uſes; in things of moment,
Concerning things I grant yee, not things errant,
Sweet Ladies things, and things to thank the Surgeon:
In no ſuch things, ſweet Anthony, put caſe —

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Come, come, all will be mended: this inviſible woman
Of infinite report for ſhape and vertue,
That bred us all this trouble to no purpoſe,
They are determin'd now no more to thinke on,
But fall cloſe to their ſtudies.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Was there ever
Men knowne to run mad with report before?
Or wonder after that they know not where
To finde? or if found, how to enjoy? are mens braines
Made now a dayes of Malt, that their affections
Are never ſober? but like drunken people
Founder at every new fame? I do believe too
That men in love are ever drunke, as drunken men
Are ever loving.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Prethee be thou ſober,
And know, that they are none of thoſe, not guilty
Of the leaſt vanity of love, onely a doubt
Fame might too farre report, or rather flatter
The graces of this woman, made them curious
To finde the truth, which ſince they finde ſo blotted
And lock'd up from their ſearches, they are now ſetled
To give the wonder ever.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Would they were ſetled
To give me ſome new ſhooes too: for I'le be ſworne
Theſe are e'ne worne out to the reaſonable ſoules
In their good worſhips buſineſſe: and ſome ſleep
Would not doe much amiſſe, unleſſe they meane
To make a Bell-man on me: and what now
Meane they to ſtudy, Anthony, Morall Philoſophy
After their mar-all women?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Mar a fooles head.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: 'Twill mar two fools heads, & they take not heed,
Beſides the Giblets to 'em.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Will you walke Sir,
And talke more out of hearing? your fooles head
May chance to finde a wooden night-cap elſe.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I never lay in any. Enter Don John and Fredrick.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Then leave your lying,
And your blinde Propheſying: here they come,
You had beſt tell them as much.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I am no tell-tale. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: I would we could have ſeen her though: for ſure
She muſt be ſome rare creature, or report lyes,
All mens reports too,

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I could well wiſh I had ſeen her;
But ſince ſhe is ſo conceal'd, ſo beyond venture
Kept and preſerv'd from view, ſo like a Paradice,
Plac't where no knowledg can come near her; ſo guarded
As 'twere impoſſible, though knowne to reach her,
I have made up my beliefe.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Hang me from this houre
If I more thinke upon her, or believe her,
But as ſhe came a ſtrong report unto me,
So the next Fame ſhall looſe her.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis the next way:
But whither are you walking?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: My old round
After my meat, and then to bed.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis healthfulll.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Will not you ſtir?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I have a little buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Upon my life this Lady ſtill—

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Then you will looſe it.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Pray let's walke together.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Now I cannot.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: I have ſomething to impart.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: An houre hence
I will not miſſe to meet you.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Ith' high ſtreet;
For not to lye, I have a few Devotions
To doe firſt, then I am yours.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Remember. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaen. 2.
div.stage: Enter Petruchio, Antonio, and two Gent.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Cut his winde-pipe, I ſay.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Fie Antonio.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Or knock his brains out firſt, then forgive him
If you doe thruſt, be ſure it be to th' hilts,
A Surgeon may ſee through him.
You are too violent,
Too open, undiſcreet.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Am I not ruin'd?
The honour of my houſe crack'd? my bloud poyſon'd?
My credit, and my name?
Be ſure it be ſo,
Before ye uſe this violence. Let not doubt,
And a ſuſpecting anger ſo much ſway ye,
Your wiſedome may be queſtion'd.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I ſay kill him,
And then diſpute the cauſe; cut off what may be,
And what is, ſhall be ſafe.
Hang up a true man,
Becauſe 'tis poſſible he may be theeviſh:
Alas, is this good Juſtice?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: I know as certaine,
As day muſt come againe; as cleare as truth.
And open as beliefe can lay it to me,
That I am baſely wrong'd, wrong'd above recompence;
Malitiouſly abus'd, blaſted for ever
In name and honour, loſt to all remembrance,
But what is ſmear'd, and ſhamefull; I muſt kill him,
Neceſſitie compells me.
But think better

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: There is no other cure left: yet witneſſe with me
All that is faire in man, all that is noble,
I am not greedy of this life I ſeek for,
Nor thirſt to ſhed mans bloud; and would 'twere poſſible
I wiſh it with my ſoule, ſo much I tremble
To offend the ſacred Image of my Maker,
My ſword could onely kill his crimes: no 'tis honour,
Honour, my noble friends, that idoll honour,
That all the world now worſhips, not Petruchio
Muſt doe this juſtice.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Let it once be done,
And 'tis no matter, whether you, or honour,
Or both be acceſſarie.
Doe you weigh Petruchio
The value of the perſon, power, and greatneſſe,
And what this ſparke may kindle?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: To performe it,
So much I am ty'd to reputation,
And credit of my houſe, let it raiſe wild-ſires,
That all this Dukedome ſmoak, and ſtormes that toſſe me
Into the ſtormes of everlaſting ruine,
Yet I muſt through; if yee dare ſide me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Dare?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Ye're friends indeed, if not.
Here's none flies from you,
Doe it in what deſigne ye pleaſe, wee'll back ye.
But then be ſure yee kill him.
Is the cauſe
So mortall, nothing but his life?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Beleeve me,
A leſſe offence has been the deſolation
Of a whole name.
No other way to purge it?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: There is, but never to be hoped for,
Thinke an houre more,
And if then ye finde no ſafer road to guide yee,
Wee'll ſet up our reſts too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Mine's up already,
And hang him for my part,
Goes leſſe than life.
If we ſee noble cauſe, 'tis like our ſwords
May be as free and forward as your words. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: The civill order of this Towne Bellonia
Makes it belov'd, and honour'd of all travellers,
As a moſt ſafe retirement in all troubles;
Beſide the wholſome ſeat, and noble temper
Of thoſe mindes that inhabit it, ſafely wiſe,
And to all ſtrangers vertuous: But I ſee
My admiration has drawne night upon me,
And longer to expect my friend may pull me
Into ſuſpition of too late a ſtirrer,
Which all good Governments are jealous of.
Ile home, and thinke at liberty: yet certaine,
'Tis not ſo farre night as I thought; for ſee,
A faire houſe yet ſtands open, yet all about it
Are cloſe, and no lights ſtirring: there may be foule play:
Ile venture to look in: if there be knaves,
I may doe a good office. Woman within.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: Signieur?

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: What? how is this?

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: Signieur Fabritio?

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Ile goe nearer.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: This is a womans tongue, here may be good done.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: Where are ye?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: O come, for heavens ſake!

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: I muſt ſee what this meanes,

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: I have ſtay'd this long houre for you, make no noiſe,
For things are in ſtrange trouble: here, be ſecret,
'Tis worth your care; begone now; more eyes watch us,
Then may be for our ſafeties.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Harke ye?

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: Peace: good night.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: She is gone, and I am loaden; fortune for me;
It weighes well, and it feeles well; it may chance
To be ſome pack of worth: by th' maſſe 'tis heavie;
If it be Coyne or Jewels, 'tis worth welcome:
Ile ne're refuſe a fortune: I am confident
'Tis of no common price: now to my lodging:
If it hit right, Ile bleſſe this night. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis ſtrange,
I cannot meet him; ſure he has encountred
Some light o' love or other, and there meanes
To play at In and In for this night. Well Don John,
If you doe ſpring a leak, or get an itch,
Til ye claw off your curl'd pate, thank your night-walks:
You muſt be ſtill a bootehalling: one round more,
Though it be late, Ile venture to diſcover ye,
I doe not like your out-leaps.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Welcome to Towne, are ye all fit?
To point Sir,

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Where are the horſes?
Where they were appointed.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Be private, and whatſoever fortune
Offer it ſelfe, let's ſtand ſure.
Feare not us,
'Ere ye ſhall be endangered, or deluded,
Wee'll make a black night on't.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: No more, I know it;
You know your Quarters?
Will you goe alone ſir?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Ye ſhall not be farre from me, the leaſt noiſe
Shall bring ye to my reſcue.
We are counſell'd. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Was ever man ſo paid for being curious?
Ever ſo bob'd for ſearching out adventures,
As I am? did the devill lead me? muſt I needs be peeping
Into mens houſes where I had no buſineſſe,
And make my ſelfe a miſchiefe? 'Tis well carried;
I muſt take other mens occaſions on me,
And be I know not whom: moſt finely handled:
What have I got by this now? what's the purchaſe?
A piece of evening Arras worke, a childe,
Indeed an Infidell: this comes of peeping:
A lumpe got out of lazineſſe; good white bread
Let's have no bawling with yee: 'ſdeath, have I
Knowne Wenches thus long, all the wayes of wenches,
Their ſnares and ſubtilties? have I read over
All their Schoole learnings, div'd into their quiddits,
And am I now bum-fidled with a Baſtard?
Fetch'd over with a Carde of five, and in mine old dayes,
After the dire maſſacre of a million
Of Maiden-heads? caught the common way, ith'night too
Under anothers name, to make the matter
Carry more weight about it? well Don Iohn,
You will be wiſer one day, when ye have purchas'd
A beavy of theſe Butter prints together,
With ſearching out conceal'd iniquities,
Without commiſſion: why, it would never grieve me,
If I had got this Ginger-bread: never ſtirr'd me,
So I had had a ſtroak for't: 't had been Juſtice
Then to have kept it; but to raiſe a dayrie
For other mens adulteries, conſume my ſelfe in candles,
And ſcowring works, in Nurſes Bells and Babies,
Onely for charity, for meere I thank you,
A little troubles me: the leaſt touch for it,
Had but my breeches got it, had contented me.
Whoſe e're it is, ſure t' had a wealthy mother,
For 'tis well cloathed, and if I be not cozen'd,
Well lin'd within: to leave it here were barbarous,
And ten to one would kill it: a more ſin
Then his that got it: well, I will diſpoſe on't,
And keep it, as they keep deaths heads in rings,
To cry, memento to me; no more peeping.
Now all the danger is to qualifie
The good old gentlewoman, at whoſe houſe we live,
For ſhe will fall upon me with a Catechiſme
Of foure houres long: I muſt endure all;
For I will know this mother: Come good wonder,
Let you and I be jogging: your ſtarv'd trebble
Will waken the rude watch elſe: All that bee
Curious night-walkers, may they finde my fee. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Sure hee's gone home:
I have beaten all the purlewes,
But cannot bolt him: if he be a bobbing
'Tis not my care can cure him: To morrow morning
I ſhall have further knowledge from a Surgeons—
Where he lyes moord, to mend his leaks.

sp.speaker: Con,
sp.l: I'me ready,
And through a world of dangers am ſlown to yee.
Be full of haſte and care, we are undone elſe:
Where are your people? which way muſt we travell?
For heaven ſake ſtay not here ſir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: What may this prove?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Alas I am miſtaken, loſt, undone.
For ever periſh'd. Sir, for heaven ſake tell me,
Are ye a Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I am.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Of this place?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: No, borne in Spain.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: As ever you lov'd honour,
As ever your deſires may gaine their ends,
Doe a poore wretched woman but this benefit,
For I am forc'd to truſt yee.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Y'ave charm'd me,
Humanity and honour bids me helpe ye;
And if I faile your truſt.—

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: The time's too dangerous
To ſtay your proteſtations: I beleeve ye,
Alas, I muſt believe ye: From this place,
Good noble Sir, remove me inſtantly,
And for a time, where nothing but your ſelfe,
And honeſt converſation my come neare me,
In ſome ſecure place ſettle me. What I am,
And why thus boldly I commit my credit
Into a ſtrangers hand, the feares and dangers,
That force me to this wilde courſe, at more leiſure
I ſhall reveale unto you.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Come, be hearty,
He muſt ſtrike through my life that takes ye from me.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: He will ſure come. Are yee well arm'd?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Never feare us.
Here's that will make 'em dance without a Fiddle.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: We are to look for no weak foes, my friends,
Nor unadviſed ones.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Beſt gamſters make the beſt game,
We ſhall fight cloſe and handſome then.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: You are a thought too bloudy.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why? all Phyſitians
And penny Almanacks allow the opening
Of veines this moneth: why doe ye talke of bloudy?
What come we for, to fall to cuffes for apples?
What, would ye make the Cauſe a Cudgell quarell?
On what termes ſtands this man? is not his honour
Open'd to his hand, and pickt out like an Oyſter?
His credit like a quart pot knockt together,
Able to hold no liquor? cleare but this point.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Speak ſoftly, gentle Couzen.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ile ſpeak truely;
What ſhould men doe ally'd to theſe diſgraces,
Lick o're his enemie, ſit downe, and dance him?
You are as farre o'th' bow hand now.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And crie;
That's my fine boy, thou wilt doe ſo no more child.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Here are no ſuch cold pitties.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: By Saint Jaques
They ſhall not finde me one: here's old tough Andrew,
A ſpeciall friend of mine, and he but hold,
He ſtrike 'em ſuch a horne-pipe: knocks I come for,
And the beſt bloud I light on; I profes it,
Not to ſcarre Coſter-mongers; If I looſe mine owne,
Mine audits loſt, and fare-well five and fifty.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Let's talke no longer, place your ſelves with ſilence,
As I directed yee; and when time calls us,
As ye are friends, ſo ſhew your ſelves.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: So be it. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena. 9.
div.stage: Enter Don John and his Land-lady.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Nay Son, if this be your regard.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Good mother.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Good me no goods; your Cozen, and your ſelf
Are welcome to me, whilſt you beare your ſelves
Like honeſt and true Gentlemen: Bring hither
To my houſe, that have ever been reputed
A gentlewoman of a decent, and faire carriage,
And ſo behav'd my ſelf?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: I know ye have.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Bring hither, as I ſay, to make my name
Stinke in my neighbours noſtrills? your Deviſes,
Your Brats, got out of Alligant, and broken oathes?
Your Linſey Woolſey worke, your haſty puddings?
I foſler up your filch'd iniquities?
Y'are deceiv'd in me, Sir, I am none
Of thoſe receivers.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Have I not ſworne unto you,
'Tis none of mine, and ſhew'd you how I found it?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Ye found an eaſie foole that let you get it,
She had better have worne paſtornes.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Will yee heare me?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Oathes? what doe you care for oathes to gaine your ends,
When ye are high and pamper'd? What Saint know ye?
Or what Religion, but your purpos'd lewdneſſe,
Is to be look'd for of ye? nay, I will tell ye,
You will then ſweare like accus'd Cut-purſes,
As far of truth too; and lye beyond all Faulconers:
I'me ſick to ſee this dealing.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Heaven forbid Mother.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: Nay, I am very ſick.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Who waits there?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sir. within.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Bring down the bottle of Canary wine.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Exceeding ſick, heav'n helpe me.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Haſte ye ſirrah,
I muſt ev'n make her drunk; nay gentle mother;

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Now ſie upon ye, was it for this purpoſe
You fetch'd your evening walks for your digeſtions,
For this pretended holineſſe? no weather,
Not before day could hold ye from the Matins.
Were theſe your bo-peep prayers? ye have praid well,
And with a learned zeale: watcht well too; your Saint
It ſeems was pleas'd as well: ſtill ſicker, ſicker.
sp.stage: Enter Anthony with a bottle of wine.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: There is no talking to her till I have drencht her.
Give me: here mother take a good round draught,
'Twill purge ſpleen from your ſpirits: deeper mother.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I, I, ſonne; you imagine this will mend all.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: All y'faith Mother.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I confeſſe the Wine
Will doe his part.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Ile pledge ye.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: But ſonne John.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: I know your meaning mother; touch it once more,
Alas you look not well; take a round draught,
It warmes the bloud well, and reſtores the colour,
And then wee'll talke at large.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: A civill gentleman?
A ſtranger? one the Town holds a good regard of?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Nay I will ſilence there.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: One that ſhould weigh his faire name? oh, a ſtichl

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: There's nothing better for a ſtitch, good mother,
Make no ſpare of it, as you love your health,
Mince not the nutter.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: As I ſaid, a gentleman,
Lodge in my houſe? now heav'ns my comfort, Signior!

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: I look'd for this.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I did not thinke you would havo us'd me thus;
A woman of my credit: one, heaven knowes,
That lov'd you but too tenderly.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Deare mother,
I ever found your kindneſſe, and acknowledge it.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: No, no, I am a fool to counſell yee. Where's the infant?
Come, lets ſee your Workmanſhip.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: None of mine, Mother.
But there 'tis, and a luſty one.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Heaven bleſſe thee,
Thou hadſt a haſty making; but the beſt is,
'Tis many a good mans fortune: as I live
Your owne eyes Signior, and the nether lip
As like yee, as ye had ſpit it.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: I am glad on't.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Bleſſe me, what things are theſe?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: I thought my labour
Was not all loſt, 'tis gold, & theſe are jewels,
Both rich, and right I hope.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Well, well ſonne Iohn,
I ſee ye are a wood-man, and can chuſe
Your Deere, though it be i'th darke, all your diſcretion
Is not yet loſt; this was well clapt aboard:
Here I am with you now; when as they ſay
Your pleaſure comes with profit; when ye muſt needs do,
Doe where ye may be done to, 'tis a wiſedome
Becomes a young man well: be ſure of one thing,
Looſe not your labour and your time together,
It ſeaſons of a foole, ſonne, time is pretious,
Worke wary whilſt ye have it; ſince ye muſt traffick
Sometimes this ſlippery way, take ſure hold Signior,
Trade with no broken Merchants, make your lading,
As you would make your reſt, adventurouſly,
But with advantage ever.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: All this time mother,
The childe wants looking too, wants meat and Nurſes.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Now bleſſing o' thy care; it ſhall have all,
And inſtantly; Ile ſeek a Nurſe my ſelfe, ſonne;
'Tis a ſweet childe: ah my young Spaniard;
Take you no further care ſir.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Yes of theſe Jewels,
I muſt by your leave Mother: theſe are yours,
To make your care the ſtronger: for the reſt
Ile finde a Maſter; the gold for bringing up on't,
I freely render to your charge.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: No more words,
Nor no more children, (good ſonne) as you love me,
This may doe well.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: I ſhall obſerve your Morals.
But where's Don Ferdinand (Mother)

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Ten to one
About the like adventure: he told me.
He was to finde you out. Exit.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Why ſhould he ſtay thus?
There may be ſome ill chance in't: ſleep I will not,
Before I have found him: now this woman's pleas'd,
Ile ſeek my friend out, and my care is eas'd. Exit.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Beleeve ſir, 'tis as poſſible to doe it,
As to remove the City; the maine faction,
Swarm throgh the ſtreets like hornets, arm'd with angers
Able to ruine States: no ſafety left us,
Nor meanes to dye like men, if inſtantly
You draw not back againe,

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: May he be drawne
And quarter'd too, that turnes now; were I ſurer
Of death then thou art of thy fears, and with death
More then thoſe feares are too.
Sir, I feare not.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I would not crack my vow, ſtart from my honour,
Becauſe I may finde danger; wound my ſoule,
To keep my body ſafe.
I ſpeak not ſir,
Out of a baſeneſſe to you.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: No, nor doe not
Out of a baſeneſſe leave mo: what is danger,
More then the weakneſſe of our apprehenſions?
A poor cold part o'th bloud? who takes it hold of?
Cowards, and wicked livers: valiant mindes
Were made the Maſters of it, and as hearty Seamen
In deſperate ſtormes, ſtem with a little Rudder
The tumbling ruines of the Ocean:
So with their cauſe & ſwords do they do dangers.
Say we yere ſure to dye all in this venture,
As I am confident againſt it: is there any
Amongſt us of ſo fat a ſenſe, ſo pamper'd,
Would chule luxuriouſly to lye a bed,
And purge away his ſpirit, ſend his ſoule out
In Sugar-lops, and Syrups? give me dying,
As dying out to be, upon mine enemy,
Parting with man-kinde, by a man that's manly:
Let 'em be all the world, and bring along
Cain's envy with 'em, I will on.
You may ſir,
But with what ſafety?
Since 'tis come to dying,
You ſhall perceive ſir, here be thoſe amongſt us
Can dye as decently as other men,
And with as little ceremony: on brave ſir.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: That's ſpoken heartily.
And he that flinches
May he dye lowzie in a ditch.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: No more dying,
There's no ſuch danger in it:
What's a clock?
Somewhat above your houre.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Away then quickly,
Make no noiſe, and no trouble will attend us. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena. 11.
div.stage: Enter Fredericke, and Peter, (with a candle.)

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Give me the candle: ſo goe you out that way.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: What have we now to doe?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: And o' your life ſirrah,
Let none come neare the doore without my knowledge,
No not my Land lady, nor my friend.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: 'Tis done ſir.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Nor any ſerious buſineſſe that concerns me.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Is the winde there agen?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Be gone.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I am ſir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Now enter without feare.—And noble Lady
That ſafety and civility yee wiſh'd for
Shall truely here attend you: no rude tongue
Nor rough behaviour knows this place, no wiſhes
Beyond the moderation of a man,
Dare enter here: your owne deſires and Innocence,
Joyn'd to my vow'd obedience, ſhall protect you,
Were dangers more then doubts.

sp.speaker: Coaſt.
sp.l: Ye are truely noble,
And worth a womans truſt: let it become me,
(I doe beſeech you ſir) for all your kindneſſe,
To render with my thanks, this worthleſſe trifle;
I may be longer troubleſome.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Faire offices
Are ſtill their owne rewards: Heav'n bleſſe me Lady
From ſelling civill courteſies: may it pleaſe ye,
If ye will force a favour to oblige me,
Draw but that cloud aſide, to ſatisfie me
For what good Angel I am engag'd,

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: It ſhall be.
For I am truely confident yee are honeſt:
The Piece is ſcarce worth looking on.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Truſt me
The abſtract of all beauty, ſoule of ſweetneſſe,
Defend me honeſt thoughts, I ſhall grow wilde elſe:
What eyes are there, rather what little heavens,
To ſtirre mens contemplations? what a Paradice
Runs through each part ſhe has? good bloud be temperate:
I muſt look off: too excellent an object
Confounds the ſenſe that ſees it Noble Lady,
If there be any further ſervice to caſt on me,
Let it be worth my life, ſo much I honour ye,
Or the engagement of whole Families.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: Your ſervice is too liberall, worthy ſir,
Thus farre I ſhall entreat.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Command me Lady.
You make your power too poore.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: That preſently
With all convenient haſte, you would retire
Unto the ſtreet you found me in.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis done.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: There, if you finde a gentleman oppreſt
With force and violence, doe a mans office,
And draw your ſword to reſcue him.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Hee's ſafe,
Be what he will, and let his foes be devills,
Arm'd with your pitty, I ſhall conjure 'em.
Retire, this key will guide ye: all things neceſſary
Are there before ye.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: All my prayers goe with ye. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Ye clap on proof upon me: men ſay gold
Do's all, engages all, works through all dangers:
Now I ſay beauty can do more: The Kings Exchequer,
Nor all his wealthy Indies, could not draw me
Through halfe thoſe miſeries this peece of pleaſure
Might make me leap into: we are all like ſea-Cards,
All our endeavours and our motions,
(As they doe to the North) ſtill point at beauty,
Still at the faireſt: for a handſome woman,
(Setting my ſoule a ſide) it ſhould goe hard,
But I would ſtraine my body: yet to her,
Unleſſe it be her owne free gratitude,
Hopes ye ſhall dye, and thou tongue rot within me,
E're I infringe my faith: now to my reſcue. Exit.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Duke, purſued by Petruchio, Antonio, and that Faction.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: YOu will not all oppreſſe me?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Kill him ith' wanton eye: let me come to him.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Then yee ſhall buy me dearely.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Say you ſo ſir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I ſay cut his Wezand ſpoile his peeping.
Have at your love-ſick heart ſir. Enter Don John.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Sure 'tis fighting.
My friend may be engag'd: fie gentlemen,
This is unmanly oddes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Ile ſtop your mouth ſir. Du. fals down, Don Ioh. be|ſtrides him.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Nay, then have at thee freely:
Ther's a plumb ſir to ſatisfie your longing.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Away: I hope I have ſped him: here comes reſcue.
We ſhall be endangered: where's Antonio?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I muſt have one thruſt more ſir.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Come up to me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A miſchiefe confound your fingers.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: How is't?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Well:
Ha's giv'n me my quiet us eſt, I felt him
In my ſmall guts, I'me ſure, has feez'd me:
This comes of ſiding with ye.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Can you goe ſir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I ſhould goe man, and my head were of,
Never talke of going.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Come, all ſhall be well then. Enter the Dukes Faction.
I heare more reſcue comming.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Let's turne back then;
My skull's uncloven yet, let me but kill.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Away for heaven ſake with him.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: How is't?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Well ſir,
Onely a little ſtagger'd.

sp.speaker: Faction Du.
sp.l: Lets purſue 'em.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: No not a man, I charge ye: thanks good coat,
Thou haſt ſav'd me a ſhrewd welcome: 't was put home too,
With a good minde I'me ſure on't.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Are ye ſafe then?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: My thanks to you brave ſir, whoſe timely valour,
And manly courteſie came to my reſcue,

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Ye' had foule play offer'd ye, and ſhame befall him
That can paſſe by oppreſſion.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: May I crave ſir,
But thus much honour more, to know your name?
And him I am ſo bound to?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: For the Bond ſir,
'Tis every good mans tye: to know me further
Will little profit ye; I am a ſtranger,
My Countrey Spaine; my name Don Iohn, a gentleman
That lyes here for my ſtudy.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I have heard ſir,
Much worthy mention of ye, yet I finde
Fame ſhort of what ye are.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: You are pleas'd ſir,
To expreſſe your courteſie: may I demand
As freely what you are, and what miſchance
Caſt you into this danger?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: For this preſent
I muſt deſire your pardon: you ſhall know me
Ere it be long ſir, and a nobler thanks,
Then now my will can render.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Your will's your owne ſir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What is't you look for ſir, have yee loſt any thing?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Onely my hat i'th ſcuffle; ſure theſe fellowes
Were night-ſnaps.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: No, believe ſir: pray ye uſe mine,
For 'twil be hard to finde your owne now.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: No ſir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Indeed ye ſhall, I can command another:
I doe beſeech ye honour me.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: I will ſir,
And ſo Ile take my leave.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Within theſe few dayes
I hope I ſhall be happy in your knowledge.
Till when I love your memory. Exit Duke, &c. Enter Fredrick.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: I yours.
This is ſome noble fellow.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis his tongue ſure.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Ye' are fairely met ſir:
I thought ye had been a Bat-fowling: prethee tell me,
What Revelations haſt thou had to night,
That home was never thought of?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Revelations?
Ile tell thee Fredrick. but before I tell thee,
Settle thy underſtanding.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis prepar'd, ſir.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Why then mark what ſhall follow. This night Fredr.
This bawdy night.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I thought no leſſe.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: This blinde night,
What doſt think I have got?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: The Pox it may be.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Would 'twere no worſe: ye talke of Revelations,
I have got a Revelation will reveale me,
An arrant Coxcombe while I live.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: What is't?
Thou haſt loſt nothing?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: No, I have got I tell thee.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: What haſt thou got?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: One of the Infantry, a childe.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: A chopping child, man.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Give ye joy, ſir.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: A lump of lewdneſſe Fredrick, that's the truth on't:
This Town's abominable.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I ſtill told ye Iohn
Your whoring muſt come home; I counſell'd ye:
But where no grace is—

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: 'Tis none o'mine, man.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Anſwer the Pariſh ſo.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Cheated introth.
Peeping into a houſe, by whom I know not,
Nor where to find the place agen: no Fredricke,
Had I but kiſt the ring fort; 'tis no poor one,
That's my beſt comfort, for't has brought about it
Enough to make it man.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Where is't?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: At home.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: A ſaving voyage: But what will you ſay Signior,
To him that ſearching out your ſerious Worſhip,
Has met a ſtranger fortune?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: How, good Frederick?
A militant girle now to this boy would hit it?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: No, mine's a nobler venture: What do you think Sir
Of a diſtreſſed Lady, one whoſe beauty
Would overſell all Italy?

sp.speaker: Joh,
sp.l: Where is ſhe—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: A woman of that rare behaviour,
So qualified, as admiration
Dwels round about her: of that perfect ſpirit—

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: I marry Sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: That admirable carriage,
That ſweetnes in diſcourſe; young as the morning,
Her bluſhes ſtaining his.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: But where's this Creature?
Shew me but that.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: That's all one, ſhee's forth comming,
I have her ſure Boy.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Harke ye Fredrick.
What truck betwixt my Infant?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis too light Sir,
Stick to your charges good Don John, I am well.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: But is there ſuch a wench?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Firſt tell me this,
Did ye not lately as ye walk'd along,
Diſcover people that were arm'd, and likely
To doe offence?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Yes mary, and they urg'd it
As far as they had ſpirit.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Pray goe forward.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: A Gentleman I found ingag'd amongſt e'm,
It ſeemes of noble breeding, I'm ſure brave mettall,
As I return'd to looke you, I ſet in to him,
And without hurt (I thanke heaven) reſcued him,
And came my ſelfe off ſafe too.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: My work's done then:
And now to ſatisfie you, there is a woman,
Oh Iohn, there is a woman—

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Oh, where is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: And one of no leſſe worth then I aſſure ye;
And which is more, falne under my protection.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: I am glad of that: forward ſweet Fredrick.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: And which is more then that, by this nights wandring,
And which is moſt of all, ſhe is at home too Sir.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Come, lets be gone then.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Yes, but 'tis moſt certaine,
You cannot ſee her, Iohn.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: She has ſworne me
That none elſe ſhall come neare her: not my Mother
Till ſome few doubts are clear'd.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Not look upon her? What chamber is ſhe in?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: In ours.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Let's goe I ſay:
A womans oathes are wafers, breake with making,
They muſt for modeſtie a litle: we all know it.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: No, I'le aſſure you Sir.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Not ſee her?
I ſmell an old dog trick of yours, well Fredrick,
Ye talkt to me of whoring, let's have faire play,
Square dealing I would wiſh ye.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: When 'tis come.
Which I know never will be, to that iſſue,
Your ſpoone ſhall be as deep as mine Sir.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Tell me,
And tell me true, is the cauſe honourable,
Or for your eaſe?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: By all our friendſhip, Iohn,
'Tis honeſt, and of great end.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: I am anſwer'd:
But let me ſee her though: leave the doore open
As yee goe in.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I dare not.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Not wide open,
But juſt ſo, as a jealous husband
Would levell at his wanton wife through.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: That courteſie,
If ye deſire no more, and keep it ſtrictly,
I dare afford yee: come, 'tis now neare morning. Ex.

div.head: Scaene 2.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Nay the old woman's gone too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Shee's a Catterwauling
Among the gutters: But conceive me, Peter,
Where our good Maſters ſhould be?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Where they ſhould be,
I doe conceive, but where they are, good Anthony—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I, there it goes: my Maſters bo-peep with me,
With his ſlye popping in and out agen,
Argued a cauſe, a frippery cauſe.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Beleeve me,
They bear up with ſome carvell.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I doe believe thee,
For thou haſt ſuch a Maſter for that chaſe,
That till he ſpend his maine Maſt—

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Pray remember
Your courteſie good Anthony; and withall,
How long 'tis ſince your Maſter ſprung a leak,
He had a ſound one ſince he came. Lute ſounds within.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Harke.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Doeſt not hear a Lute?
Agen?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Where is't?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Above in my Maſters chamber.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: There's no creature: he hath the key himſelf man.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: This is his Lute: let him have it. Sing within a little.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I grant you; but who ſtrikes it?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: An admirable voice too, harke ye.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Art ſure we are at home?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Without all doubt, Peter.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Then this muſt be the Devill.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Let it be. Sing agen.
Good Devill ſing againe: O dainty devill,
Peter beleve it, a moſt delicate devill,
The ſweeteſt Devill— Enter Fredrick & Don Iohn.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: If ye could leave peeping.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: I cannot by no meanes.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Then come in ſoftly,
And as ye love your faith, preſume no further
Then yee have promiſed.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: What make you up ſo early ſir?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: You ſir in your contemplations.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: O pray ye peace ſir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Why peace ſir?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Doe you heare?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: 'Tis your Lute.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Pray yee ſpeak ſoftly.
She's playing on't.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The houſe is haunted ſir,
For this we have heard this halfe yeare.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Ye ſaw nothing;

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Nor I Sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Get us our breakfaſt then,
And make no words on't; wee'll undertake this ſpirit,
If it be one.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: This is no devill Peter. Sing. Exeunt Servants.
Mum, there be Bats abroad.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Stay, now ſhe ſings.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: An Angels voice Ile ſweare.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Why did'ſt thou ſhrug ſo?
Either allay this heat; or as I live
I will not truſt ye.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Paſſe: I warrant ye. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: To curſe thoſe ſtarres, that men ſay governe us,
To raile at fortune, fall out with my Fate,
And taske the generall world, will helpe me nothing:
Alas, I am the ſame ſtill, neither are they
Subject to helpes, or hurts: Our owne deſires
Are our owne fates, our owne ſtars, all our fortunes,
Which as we ſway 'em, ſo abuſe, or bleſſe us.

div.stage: Enter Fredrick, and Don John peeping.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Peace to your meditations.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Pox upon ye,
Stand out oth' light.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: I crave your mercy ſir,
My minde o're-charg'd with care made me unmannerly.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Pray yee ſet that minde at reſt, all ſhall be perfect.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: I like the body rare; a handſome body,
A wondrous handſome body: would ſhe would turne:
See, and that ſpightfull puppy be not got
Between me and my light againe,

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Tis done,
As all that you command ſhall bee: the gentleman
Is ſafely off all danger.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: How ſhall I thank ye ſir? how ſatisfie?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Speak ſoftly, gentle Lady, all's rewarded,
Now does he melt like Marmalad.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Nay, 'tis certaine,
Thou art the ſweeteſt woman I e're look'd on:
I hope thou art not honeſt.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: None diſturb'd yee?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Not any ſir, nor any ſound came neare me,
I thank your care.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis well.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: I would faine pray now,
But the Devill and that fleſh there, o' the world,
What are we made to ſuffer?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Hee'll enter;
Pull in your head and be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Harke ye Fredricke,
I have brought ye home your Pack-ſaddle.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Pox upon yee.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Nay let him enter: fie my Lord the Duke,
Stand peeping at your friends.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Ye are cozen'd Lady,
Here is no Duke.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: I know him full well Signior.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Hold thee there wench.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: This mad-brain'd foole will ſpoile all.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I doe beſeech your grace come in.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: My Grace,
There was a word of comfort.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Shall he enter,
Who e're he be?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Well follow'd Fredrick.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Come in then. Enter Don John.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: 'Bleſſe yee Lady:

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Nay ſtart not, though he be a ſtranger to ye,
Hee's of a Noble ſtraine, my kinſman, Lady,
My Countrey-man, and fellow Traveller,
One bed containes us ever, one purſe feeds us,
And one faith free between us; do not fear him,
Hee's truely honeſt.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: That's a lye.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: And truſty:
Beyond your wiſhes: valiant to defend,
And modeſt to converſe with, as your bluſhes.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Now may I hang my ſelf; this commendation
Has broke the neck of all my hopes: for now
Muſt I cry, no forſooth, and I forſooth, and ſurely,
And truely as I live,, and as I am honeſt.
Has done theſe things for 'nonce too; for hee knowes,
Like a moſt envious Raſcall as he is,
I am not honeſt, nor deſire to be,
Eſpecially this way: h'as watch'd his time,
But I ſhall quit him.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Sir, I credit ye.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Goe kiſſe her John.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Plague o' your commendations.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Sir, I ſhall now deſire to be a trouble.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Never to me, ſweet Lady: Thus I ſeale
My faith, and all my ſervice.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: One word Signeur.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Now 'tis impoſſible I ſhould be honeſt,
She kiſſes with a conjuration
Would make the devill dance: what points ſhe at?
My leg I warrant, or my well knit body:
Sit faſt Don Fredrick.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Twas given him by that gentleman
You took ſuch care of; his owne being loſt ith' ſcuffle.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: With much joy may he weare it: 'tis a right one,
I can aſſure ye Gentleman, and right happy
May you be in all fights for that faire ſervice.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Why doe ye bluſh?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: 'T had almoſt cozen'd me,
For not to lye, when I ſaw that, I look'd for
Another Maſter of it: but 'tis well. Knock within.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Who's there? Ent. Anthony.
Stand ye a little cloſe: Come in Sir,
Now what's the newes with you?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: There is a gentlemen without,
Would ſpeak with Don John,

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Who ſir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I do not know Sir, but he ſhews a man
Of no meane reckoning.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Let him ſhew his name,
And then returne a little wiſer.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Well Sir. Exit Anthony.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: How doe you like her Iohn?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: As well as you Fredrick,
For all I am honeſt: you ſhall finde it ſo too.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Art thou not honeſt?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Art thou an Aſſe?
And modeſt as her bluſhes? What a block-head
Would e're have popt out ſuch a dry Apologie,
For his deare friend? and to a Gentlewoman,
A woman of her youth, and delicacy.
They are arguments to draw them to abhorre us.
An honeſt morall man; 'tis for a Conſtable:
A handſome man, a wholſome man, a tough man,
A liberall man, a likely man, a man
Made up like Hercules, unſlak'd with ſervice:
The ſame to night, to morrow night, the next night,
And ſo to perpetuitie of pleaſures,
Theſe had been things to hearken too, things catching:
But you have ſuch a ſpiced conſideration,
Such qualmes upon your worſhips conſcience,
Such-chil-blaines in your bloud, that all things pinch ye,
Which nature, and the liberall world makes cuſtome,
And nothing but faire honour, O ſweet honour,
Hang up your Eunuch honour: That I was truſty,
And valiant, were things well put in; but modeſt!
A modeſt gentleman I ô wit where waſt thou?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I am ſorrie John,

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: My Ladies gentlewoman
Would laugh me to a Schoole-boy, make me bluſh
With playing with my Codpeece point: fie on thee,
A man of thy diſcretion?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: It ſhall be mended:
And henceforth yee ſhall have your due. Enter Anthony.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: I look fort: How now, who is't?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: A gentleman of this towne
And calls himſelfe Petruchio. Enter Conſtantia.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Ile attend him.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: How did he call himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Doe's it concerne you ought?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: O gentlemen,
The houre of my deſtruction is come on me,
I am diſcover'd, loſt, left to my ruine:
As ever ye had pitty—

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Doe not feare,
Let the great devill come, he ſhall come through me:
Loſt here, and we about ye?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Fall before us?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: O my unfortunate eſtate, all angers
Compar'd to his, to his—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Let his, and all mens,
Whilſt we have power and life: ſtand up for heaven ſake.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I have offended heaven too; yet heaven knows—

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: We are all evill:
Yet heaven forbid we ſhould have our deſerts.
What is a?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Too too neare to my offence ſir;
O he will cut me peece-meale.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Tis no Treaſon?

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Let it be what it will: if a cut here,
Ile finde him cut-worke.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: He muſt buy you deare,
With more than common lives.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Feare not, nor weep not:
By heaven Ile fire the Towne before yee periſh,
And then, the more the merrier, wee'll jog with yee.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Come in, and dry your eyes.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Pray no more weeping:
Spoile a ſweet face for nothing? my returne
Shall end all this I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Heaven grant it. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: This man ſhould be of ſpeciall rank:
For theſe commends carry no common way,
No ſlight worth with 'em:
A ſhall be he. Ent. Don Iohn.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: 'Save yee ſir: I am ſorrie
My buſineſſe was ſo unmannerly, to make ye
Wait thus long here.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Occaſions muſt be ſerv'd ſir:
But is your name Don John?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: It is Sir.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Then,
Firſt, for your owne brave ſake I muſt embrace yee:
Next, from the credit of your noble friend
Hernando de Aluara, make yee mine:
Who layes his charge upon me in this Letter
To look yee out, and for the goodneſſe in yee,
Whilſt your occaſions make yee reſident
In this place, to ſupply yee, love and honour yee;
Which had I knowne ſooner—

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Noble ſir,
You'll make my thanks too poore: I weare a ſword, ſir,
And have a ſervice to be ſtill diſpos'd of,
As you ſhall pleaſe command it.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Gentle ſir,
That manly courteſie is half my buſineſſe:
And to be ſhort, to make ye know I honour ye,
And in all points believe your worth like Oracle,
And how above my friends, which are not few,
And thoſe not ſlack, I eſtimate your vertues,
Make your ſelfe underſtand, This day Petruchio,
A man that may command the ſtrength of this place,
Hazzard the boldeſt ſpirits; hath made choice
Onely of you, and in a noble office.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Forward, I am free to entertaine it.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Thus then:
I doe beſeech ye mark me.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: I ſhall doe it.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Ferrara's Duke, would I might call him wort hie,
But that he has raz'd out from his family,
As he has mine with Infamie, This man,
Rather this powerfull Monſter, we being left
But two of all our houſe, to ſtock out memories,
My Siſter, and my ſelfe; with arts, and witch-crafts,
Vowes, and ſuch oathes heaven has no mercy for,
Drew to diſhonour this weak maid, by ſtealthes,
And ſecret paſſages I knew not of,
Oft he obtain'd his wiſhes, oft abus'd her:
I am aſham'd to ſay the reſt: This purchas'd,
And his hot bloud allay'd, as friends forſake us
At a miles end upon our way, he left her,
And all our name to ruine.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: This was foule Play,
And ought to be rewarded ſo.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: I hope ſo;
He ſcap'd me yeſter-night: which if he dare
Againe adventure for, heaven pardon him,
I ſhall with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: For me, brave Signior,
What doe yee intend?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Onely, faire ſir, this truſt,
Which from the commendations of this Letter,
I dare preſume well placed, nobly to beare him
By word of mouth a ſingle challenge from me,
That man to man, if he have honour in him,
We may decide all difference.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Faire, and noble,
And I will doe it home: When ſhall I viſite ye?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Pleaſe you this after-noon, I will ride with yee:
For at a Caſtle ſix mile hence, we are ſure
To finde him.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Ile be ready.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: To attend ye,
My man ſhall wait: with all my Ex. Petr. Enter Fredr.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: My ſervice ſhall not faile yee.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: How now?

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: All's well: who doſt thou think this wench is?
Gheſſe, and thou canſt?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I cannot.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Be it knowne then,
To all men by theſe preſents, this is ſhe,
She, ſhe, and only ſhe, our curious coxcombs
Were errant two moneths after.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Who, Constantia?
Thou talk'ſt of Cocks and Bulls.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: I talke of wenches,
Of Cocks and Hens Don Frerdick; this is the Pullet
We two went proud after.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: It cannot be.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: It ſhall be;
Siſter to Don Petruchio: I know all man.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Now I beleeve.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Goe to, there has been ſtirring,
Fumbling with Linnen Fredrick.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis impoſſible,
You know her faine was pure as fire.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: That pure fire
Has melted out her maiden-head: ſhe is crickt:
We have all that hope of our ſide, boy.

sp.speaker: Fred,
sp.l: Thou tell'ſt me,
To my imagination, things incredible:
I ſee no looſe thought in her.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: That's all one,
She is looſe ith' hilts by heaven: but the world muſt know
A faire way, upon vow of marriage.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: There may be ſuch a ſlip.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: And will be Fredrick,
Whil'ſt the old game's a foot: I feare the boy too
Will prove hers too I took up.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Good circumſtance
May cure all this yet.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: There thou hitſt it, Fredrick:
Come, let's walke in and comfort her: her being here
Is nothing yet ſuſpected: anon Ile tell thee
Wherefore her brother came, who by this light
Is a brave noble fellow, and what honour
H'as done to me a ſtranger: there be Irons
Heating for ſome, will hiſte into their heart blouds,
'Ere all be ended; ſo much for this time.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Well ſir Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: CCome ye doe know.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I do not by this hand Miſtris.
But I ſuſpect.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: That if egges continue
At this price, women wil ne're be ſav'd
By their good works.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: I will know.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Yee ſhall, any thing
Lyes in my power: The Duke of Loraine now
Is ſeven thouſand ſtrong: I heard it of a fiſh-wife,
A woman of fine knowledge.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Sirrah, ſirrah.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: The Popes Buls are broke looſe too and 'tis ſuſpected
They ſhall be baited in England.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Very well ſir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: No, 'tis not ſo well neither.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: But I ſay to yee,
Who is it keeps your Maſter company?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I ſay to you, Don Iohn.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I ſay what woman?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I ſay ſo too.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I ſay againe, I will know.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I ſay 'tis fit yee ſhould.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: And I tell thee
He has a woman here.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: And I tell thee
'Tis then the better for him.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: You are no Bawd now?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Would I were able to be call'd unto it:
A worſhipfull vocation for my elders;
For as I underſtand it is a place
Fitting my betters farr.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Was ever Gentlewoman
So frumpt off with a foole? well ſawcy ſirrah,
I will know who it is, and for what purpoſe;
I pay the rent, and I will know how my houſe
Comes by theſe Inflamations: if this geere hold,
Beſt hang a ſigne-poſt up, to tell the Signiors,
Here ye may have lewdneſſe at Liverie. Ent. Fredrick.

sp.speaker: Pet,
sp.l: 'Twould be a great eaſe to your age.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: How now?
Why what's the mater Land-lady?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: What's the matter?
Ye uſe me decently among ye gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Who has abus'd her, you ſir?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: 'Ods my witneſſe
I will not be thus treated, that I will not.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I gave her no ill language.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Thou lyeſt lewdly,
Thou tookſt me up at every word I ſpoke,
As I had been a Mawkin, a flurt Gillian;
And thou thinkſt, becauſe thou canſt write & read,
Our noſes muſt be under thee.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Dare you ſirrah?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Let but the truth be known Sir, I beſeech ye,
She raves of wenches, and I know not what ſir:

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Go to, thou know'ſt too well, thou wicked varlet,
Thou inſtrument of evill.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: As I live Sir,
She is ever thus till dinner.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Get ye in,
Ile anſwer you anon ſir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: By this hand
Ile break your Poſſit pan. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Then by this hood
Ile lock the meat up.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Now your grief, what is't?
For I can gheſſe—

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Ye may with ſhame enough,
If theer were ſhame amongſt yee; nothing thought on,
But how yee may abuſe my houſe: not ſatisfi'd
With bringing home your Baſtards to undoe me,
But you muſt drill your whores here too; my patience
Becauſe I beare, and beare, and carry, all,
And as they ſay am willing to groan under)
Muſt be your make-ſport now.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: No more of theſe words.
Nor no more murmurings Lady: for you know
That I know ſomething. I did ſuſpect your anger,
But turne it preſently and handſomely,
And beare your ſelfe diſcreetly to this woman,
For ſuch a one there is indeed.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: 'Tis well ſonne.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Leaving your devils Matins, and your melanchollies,
Or we ſhall leave our lodgings.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: You have much need
To uſe theſe vagrant wayes, and to much profit:
Ye had that might content
(At home within your ſelves too) right good gentlemen,
Wholſome, and yee ſaid handſome: But you gallants,
Boaſt that I was to beleeve ye—

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Leave your ſuſpicion:
For as I live there's no ſuch thing.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Mine honour;
And 'twere not for mine honour.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Come, your honour,
Your houſe, and you too, if you dare beleeve me
Are well enough: ſleek up your ſelf, leave crying, Bowle of wipe ready.
For I muſt have yee entertain this Lady
With all civility, ſhe well deſerves it,
Together with all ſecreſie: I dare truſt yee,
For I have found ye faithfull: when you know her
You will find your owne fault; no more words, but doe it.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: You know you may command me. Ent. Don. Ioh.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Worſhipfull Lady,
How does thy Velvet ſcabbard? by this hand
Thou look'ſt moſt amiably: now could I willingly
And 'twere not for abuſing thy Geneva print there,
Venture my body with thee.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: You'll leave this roperie,
When you come to my yeares.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: By this light
Thou art not above fifteen yet, a meere girle,
Thou haſt not half thy teeth: come—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Prethee Iohn
Let her alone, ſhe has been vex'd already:
Shee'll grow ſtarke mad man.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: I would ſee her mad,
An old mad woman

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Prethee be patient.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Is like a Millers Mare, troubled with tooth-ache.
Shee'll make the rareſt faces.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Goe, and doe it,
And doe not mind this fellow.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Well Don John.
There will be times agen; when O good Mother,
What's good for a carnoſity in the Bladder?
O the green water, mother.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Doting take yee,
Doe ye remember that?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: She has payd ye now ſir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Clarry, ſweet mother, Clarry.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Are ye ſatisfied?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Ile never whore againe; never give Petticoats
And Waſtcoats at five pound a peece; good Mother,
Quickly Mother: now mock on Son.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: A devill grinde your old chaps. Exit Land.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: By this hand wench
Ile give thee a new hood for this.
Has ſhe met with your Lordſhip?
Touch-wood rake her. Enter Anthony.
Shee's a rare ghoſtly mother.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Below attends yee
The Gentlemans man ſir that was with yee.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Well Sir;
My time is come then: yet if my project hold,
You ſhall not ſtay behinde: Ile rather truſt. Enter Conſtan.
A Cat with ſweet milk Fredrick; by her face
I feele her feares are working.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: Is there no way,
I doe beſeech yee think yet, to divert
This certaine danger?

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: 'Tis impoſſible:
Their honours are engag'd.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Then there muſt be murther,
Which, Gentlemen, I ſhall no ſooner heare of,
Then make one int: you may, if you pleaſe ſir,
Make all goe leſſe yet.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Lady wer't mine owne cauſe,
I could diſpence: but loaden with my friends truſt,
I muſt go on; though generall maſſacres
As much I feare—

sp.speaker: Conſt,
sp.l: Doe ye heare ſir; for heavens pittie
Let me requeſt one love of you.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Yes any thing.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: This gentleman I find too reſolute,
Too hot, and fiery for the cauſe, as ever
You did a vertuous deed, for honours ſake
Go with him, and allay him: your fair temper
And noble diſpoſition, like wiſh'd ſhowres,
May quench thoſe eating fires, that would ſpoile all elſe.
I ſee in him deſtruction.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I will doe it;
And 'tis a wiſe conſideration,
To me, a bounteous favour: harke ye John,
I will goe with yee.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Indeed I will,
Ye goe upon a hazard: no denyall;
For as I live, Ile goe.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Then make ye ready,
For I am ſtraight a horſe-back.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: My ſword on,
I am as ready as you: what my beſt labour,
With all the Art I have can work upon 'em,
Be ſure of, and expect faire end: the old gentlewoman
Shall wait upon you; ſhe is both grave and private,
And yee may truſt her in all points.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: Ye are noble:
And ſo I kiſſe your hand.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: That ſeale for me too,
And I hope happy iſſue Lady.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: All heavens care upon yee, and my prayers.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: So,
Now my mind's at reſt.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Away, 'tis late John. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaene 2.
div.stage: Enter Antonio, a Surgeon, and 2. Gent.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Come ſir▪ be hearty: all the worſt is paſt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Give me ſome Wine.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: 'Tis death Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis a horſe ſir.
'Sbloud, to be dreſt to the tune of Ale onely,
Nothing but ſawces to my ſores.

sp.speaker: 2 Gen.
sp.l: Fie Antonio,
You muſt be govern'd.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Has given me a dam'd Gliſter,
Only of ſand and ſnow water, gentlemen,
Has almoſt ſcour'd my guts out.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.l: I have giv'n you that ſir
Is fitteſt for your ſtate.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And here he feeds me
With rotten ends of rooks, and drown'd chickens,
Stewd Pericraniums, and Pia-maters;
And when I goe to bed, by heaven 'tis true gentlemen,
He rolls me up in Lints, with Labels at 'em,
That I am juſt the man ith' Almanack,
In head and face, is Aries place.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.l: Wilt pleaſe ye
To let your friends ſee ye open'd?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Will it pleaſe you ſir
To let me have a wench: I feele my body
Open enough for that yet?

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.l: How, a wench?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why look yee gentlemen; thus I am us'd ſtill,
I can get nothing that I want.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Leave theſe things,
And let him open ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: De'ye heare Surgeon?
Send for the Muſick, let me have ſome pleaſure
To entertaine my friends, beſide your Sallads,
Your green ſalves, and your ſearches, and ſome wine too,
That I may onely ſmell to it: or by this light
Ile dye upon thy hand, and ſpoyle thy cuſtome.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Let him have Muſick. Ent. Rowl. with wine.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.l: 'Tis ith' houſe, and ready,
If he will aske no more: but wine— Muſick.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: He ſhall not drink it.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: Will theſe things pleaſe yee?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes, and let 'em ſing

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: 'Tis too long.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ile have John Dorrie,
For to that warlike tune I will be open'd.
Give me ſome drinke, have yee ſtopt the leakes well Surgeon,
All will runne out elſe?

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.l: Feare not.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sit downe Gentlemen:
And now advance your plaiſters. Song of Joh. Dorry.
Give 'em ten ſhillings friends: how doe ye finde me?
What Symptomes doe you ſee now?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: None Sir, dangerous:
But if you will be rul'd—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What time?

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.l: I can cure ye
In forty dayes, ſo you will not tranſgreſſe me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I have a dog ſhall lick me whole in twenty:
In how long canſt thou kill me?

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.l: Preſently.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Doe it; there's more delight in't.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: You muſt have patience.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Man, I muſt have buſines; this fooliſh fellow
Hinders himſelfe: I have a dozen Raſcalls
To hurt within theſe five dayes: good man mender,
Stop me up with Parſley, like ſtuft Beefe,
And let me walke abroad.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.l: Ye ſhall walke ſhortly.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: For I muſt finde Petruchio.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.l: Time enough.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Come lead him in, and let him ſleep: within theſe three dayes
Wee'll beg yee leave to play.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: And then how things fall,
Wee'll certainly informe yee.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But Surgion promiſe me
I ſhall drinke Wine then too.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.l: A little temper'd.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Nay, Ile no tempering Surgion,

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.l: Well, as't pleaſe ye,
So ye exceed not.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Farewell: and if ye finde
The Mad ſlave, that thus ſlaſht me, commend me to him,
And bid him keep his skin cloſe.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Take your reſt ſir. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I have told yee all I can, and more then yet
Thoſe Gentlemen know of me; ever truſting
Your Councell and concealement: for to me
You ſeem a worthy woman; one of thoſe
Are ſeldome found in our ſex, wiſe and vertuous,
Direct me I beſeech ye.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Ye ſay well Lady,
And hold yee to that poynt; for in theſe buſineſſes
A womans councell that conceives the matter,
(Doe ye marke me, that conceives the matter Lady)
Is worth ten mens engagements: She knows ſomething'
And out of that can worke like wax: when men
Are giddy-headed, either out of wine,
Or a more drunkenneſſe, vaine oſtentation,
Diſcovering all: there is no more keep in 'em,
Then hold upon an Eeles taile: nay 'tis held faſhion
To defame now all they can.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I, but theſe gentlemen—

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Doe not you truſt to that: theſe gentlemen
Are as all Gentlemen of the ſame Barrell:
I, and the ſelfe ſame pickle too. Be it granted,
They have us'd yee with reſpect and faire behaviour,
Yet ſince ye came: doe you know what muſt follow?
They are Spaniards, Lady, Gennets of high mettle,
Things that will thraſh the devill, or his dam,
Let 'em appeare but cloven.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Now heaven bleſſe me.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Mad Colts will court the wind: I know 'em Lady
To the leaſt haire they have; and I tell you,
Old is I am, let but the pinte pot bleſſe 'em,
They'll offer to my yeares—

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Such rude gambolls—

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: To you?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I, and ſo handle me, that oft I am forc'd
To fight of all foure for my ſafety: there's the yonger,
Don John, the arrantſt Jack in all this City:
The other, time has blaſted, yet he will ſtoop,
If not ore-flowne, and freely on the quarry;
Has been a Dragon in his dayes. Bur Tarmont,
Don Jenkin is the Devill himſelfe, the Dog-dayes,
The moſt incomprehenſible whore-maſter,
Twenty a night is nothing: Beggers, Broom-women,
And thoſe ſo miſerable, they look like famine,
Are all ſweet Ladies in his drink.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: He's a handſome Gentleman.
Pitty he ſhould be maſter of ſuch follies.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Hee's ne're without a noiſe of Sirrenges
In's pocket, thoſe proclame him; birding pills,
Waters to coole his conſcience, in ſmall Viols;
With thouſand ſuch ſufficient emblemes: the truth is,
Whoſe chaſtily he chops upon, he cares not.
He flies at all; Baſtards upon my conſcience,
He has now in making multitudes; The laſt night
He brought home one; I pitty her that bore it,
But we are all weake veſſels, ſome rich woman
(For wiſe I dare not call her) was the mother,
For it was hung with Jewels: the bearing cloath
No leſſe then Crimſon Velvet.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: 'Tis true Lady.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Was it a Boy too?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: A brave Boy; deliberation
And judgement ſhewd in's getting, as I'le ſay for him,
He's as well paced for that ſport—

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: May I ſee it?
For there is a neighbour of mine, a Gentlewoman,
Has had a late miſchance, which willingly
I would know further of; now if you pleaſe
To be ſo curteous to me.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Ye ſhall ſee it:
But what do ye thinke of theſe men now ye know 'em,
And of the cauſe I told ye of? Be wiſe,
Ye may repent too late elſe; I but tell ye
For your owne good, and as you will find it Lady.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I am advis'd.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: No more words then; do that,
And inſtantly, I told ye of be ready:
Don Iohn, I'le fit ye for your frumps,

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I ſhall be:
But ſhall I ſee this Child?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Within this halfe houre,
Let's in, and there thinke better; ſhe that's wiſe,
Leapes at occaſion firſt; the reſt pay for it. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaene 4.
div.stage: Enter Petruchio, Don Iohn. and Fredrick.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Sir, he is worth your knowledg; and a Gentleman
If I that ſo much love him, may commend him,
Of free and vertuous parts; and one, if ſoule play
Should fall upon us, for which feare I brought him,
Will not flie backe for phillips.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Ye much honour me,
And once more I pronounce ye both mine.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Stay, what Troope
Is that below i'th valley there?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Hawking I take ir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: They are ſo; 'tis the Duke, 'tis even he Gentlemen,
Sirrah, draw backe the Horſes till we call ye,
I know him by his company.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I thinke too
He bends up this way.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: So he does.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Stand you ſtill
Within that Covert till I call: you Fredrick,
By no meanes be not ſeen, unleſſe they offer
To bring on odds upon us; he comes forward,
Here will I waite him fairely: to your Cabins.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I need no more inſtruct ye?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Feare me not,
I'le give it him, and boldly. Ex: Pet. and Fred.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Feed the Hawkes up,
Wee'l flie no more to day: O my bleſt fortune,
Have I ſo fairely met the man!

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Ye have Sir,
And him you know by this,

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Sir all the honour,
And love—

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: I do beſeech your Grace ſtay there,
(For I know you too now) that love and honour
I come not to receive; nor can you give it,
Till ye appeare faire to the world; I muſt beſeech ye
Diſmiſſe your traine a little.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Walke aſide,
And out of hearing I command ye: Now Sir,

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Laſt time we met, I was a friend.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: And Nobly
You did a friends office: let your buſineſſe
Be what it may, you muſt be ſtill—

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Your pardon,
Never a friend to him, cannot be friend
To his own honour.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: In what have I tranſgreſs'd it?
Ye make a bold breach at the firſt Sir.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Bolder,
You made that breach that let in infamy
And ruine, to ſurprize a noble ſtocke.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Be plaine Sir.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: I will, and ſhort;
Ye have wrong'd a Gentleman
Little behind your ſelfe, beyond all juſtice,
Beyond mediation of all friends.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: The man, and manner of wrong?
The wrong, ye have whord his Siſter.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: What's his will in't?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: His will is to oppoſe you like a Gentleman,
And ſingle, to decide all.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Now ſtay you Sir,
And heare me with the like beliefe: this Gentleman
His Siſter that you named, 'tis true I have long loved,
Nor was that love laſcivious, as he makes it;
As true, I have enjoy'd her: no leſſe truth
I have a child by her: But that ſhe, or he,
Or any of that family are tainted
Suffer diſgrace, or ruine, by my pleaſures,
I weare a Sword to ſatisfie the world no,
And him in this cauſe when he pleaſe; for know Sir,
She is my wife, contracted before Heaven,
(Witneſſe I owe more tye to, then her Brother)
Nor will I flye from that name, vvhich long ſince
Had had the Churches approbation,
But for his jealous danger.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Sir, your pardon,
And all that was my anger, now my ſervice.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Faire ſir, I knew I ſhould convert ye; had we
But that rough man herd now too—

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: And ye ſhall Sir
Whoa, hoa, hoo.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I hope ye have laid no Ambuſh? Enter Petru.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Only friends.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: My noble Brother welcome:
Come put your Anger off, we'l have no fighting,
Unleſſe you will maintaine I am unworthy
To beare that name.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Do you ſpeake this hartely?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: upon my ſoule, and truly; the firſt Prieſt
Shall put you out of theſe doubts.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Now I love ye;
And I beſeech you pardon my ſuſpitions,
You are now more then a Brother, a brave friend too.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: The good man's over-joyd Enter Fred.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: How now, how goes it?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Why, the man 'has his mare agen, and all's well Fredrick,
The Duke profeſſes freely hee's her husband.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis a good hearing.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Yes, for modeſt Gentlemen.
I muſt preſent ye: may it pleaſe your Grace
To number this brave Gentleman, my friend
And noble kinſman, amongſt thoſe your ſervants.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: O my brave friend! you ſhowre your bounties on me
Amongſt my beſt thoughts Signior, in which number
You being worthily diſpos'd already,
May place your friend to honour me.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: My love ſir,
And where your Grace dares truſt me, all my ſervice.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Why? this is wondrcus happy: But now Brother,
Now comes the bitter to our ſweet: Conſtantia.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Why, what of her?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Nor what, nor where, do I know?
Wing'd with her feares laſt night, beyond my knowledge,
She quit my houſe, but whether—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Let not that—

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: No more good Sir, I have heard too much.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Nay ſinke not,
She cannot be ſo loſt.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Nor ſhall not Gentlemen;
Be free agen, the Ladie's found; that ſmile Sir,
Shewes ye diſtruct your Servant.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I do beſeech ye.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Ye ſhall beleeve me: by my ſoule ſhe is ſafe.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Heaven knows, I would beleeve Sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Ye may ſafely.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: And under noble uſage: this faire Gentleman
Met her in all her doubts laſt night, and to his guard
(Her feares being ſtrong upon her) ſhe gave her perſon,
who waited on her, to our lodging; where all reſpect,
Civill and honeſt ſervice now attend her.

sp.speaker: Pet
sp.l: Ye may beleeve now.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Yes, I do, and ſtrongly:
Well my good friends, or rather my good Angels,
For ye have both preſerved me; when theſe vertues
Dye in your friends remembrance—

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Good your grace
Loſe no more time in complement, 'tis too pretious,
I know it by my ſelfe, there can be no hell
To his that hangs upon his hopes; eſpecially
In way of luſtly pleaſures.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: He has hit it.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: To horſe againe then, for this night I'le crowne
With all the joyes ye wiſh for.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Happy Gentlemen. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: This is the maddeſt miſchiefe: never foole
Was ſo fubd off, as I am; made ridiculous,
And to my ſelfe, mine owne Aſſe: truſt a woman,
I'le truſt the Devill firſt; for he dare be
Better then's word ſometime: what faith have I broke?
In what obſervance failed? Let me conſider, Enter Don Iohn. and Fred.
For this is monſtrous uſage.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Let them talke,
Wee'll ride on faire and ſoftly.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Well Conſtantia,

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Conſtantia, what's this fellow? ſtay by all means.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Ye have ſpun your ſelfe a faire thred now.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Stand ſtill Iohn.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: What cauſe had you to fly? what feare poſſeſt ye?
Were you not ſafely lodg'd from all ſuſpition?
Us'd with all gentle meanes? did any know
How ye came thether, or what your ſin was.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: ſmell ſome juggling John.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Yes, Fredricks, I feare it will be found ſo.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: So ſtrangely,
Without the counſell of your friends; ſo deſperatly
To put all dangers on ye?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis ſhe.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: So deceitfully
After a ſtrangers lure?

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Did ye marke that Fredrick?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: To make ye appeare more monſter; and the Law
More cruell to reward ye? to leave all,
All that ſhould be your ſafegard, to ſeeke evils?
Was this your wiſedome? this your promiſe? well
He that incited ye—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Marke that too.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: 'Had better have plough'd farther off; now Lady,
What will your laſt friend, he that ſhould preſerve ye,
And hold your credit up, the brave Antonio,
Thinke of this ſlip? he'll to Petruchio,
And call for open juſtice.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: 'Tis ſhe Fredrick.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: But what that he is John.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I do not doubt yet
To bolt ye out, for I know certainly
Ye are about the Towne ſtill: ha, no more words. Ex.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Well.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Very well.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Diſcreetly.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Finely carried.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: You have no more of theſe tricks?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Ten to one Sir,
I ſhall meet with 'em if ye have.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Is this honeſt?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Was it in you a friends part to deale double?
I am no aſſe Don Fredrick.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: And Don Iohn,
It ſhall appeare I am no foole;
Diſgrace me to make yourſelfe a lecher?
'Tis boyiſh, 'tis baſe.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: 'Tis falſe, and moſt unmanly to upbraid me,
Nor will I be your boiſter Sir,

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Thou wanton boy, thou hadſt better have been Eunuch,
Thou common womans curteſie, then thus
Laſcivious, baſely to have bent mine honour.
A friend? I'le make a horſe my friend firſt!

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Holla, holla,
Ye kicke to faſt ſir: what ſtrange braines have you got,
That dare crow out thus bravely? I better been a Eunuch?
I privy to this dog tricke? cleare your ſelfe,
For I know where the wind ſits, and moſt nobly,
Or as I have a life—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: No more: they'r horſes. A noyſe within like horſes.
Nor ſhew no diſcontent: to morrow comes;
Let's quietly away: if ſhe be at home,
Our jealouſies are put off.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: The fellow Enter Duke, Petruchio.
We have loſt him in our ſpleenes, like fooles.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Come Gentlemen,
Now ſet on roundly; ſuppoſe ye have all miſtreſſes,
And mend your pace according,

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Then have at ye. Exeunt

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Duke, Petruchio, Fredrick, and Iohn.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: NOw to Bollonia, my moſt honoured brother,
I dare pronounce yea hearty, and ſafe welcome,
Our loves ſhall now way-lay ye; welcome Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: The ſame to you brave Sir; Don Fredrick
Will ye ſtep in, and give the Lady notice
Who comes to honour her?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Bid her be ſuddain,
We come to ſee no curious wench: a night-gowne
Will ſerve the turne: here's one that knowes her neerer.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I'le tell her what ye ſay Sir. Ex. Fred.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: My deare brother,
Ye are a merry Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Now will the ſport be
To obſerve her alterations; how like wildfire
She'll leap into your boſome; then ſeeing me,
Her conſcience, and her feares creeping upon her
Dead as a fowle at ſouſe, ſhe'll ſinke.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Faire brother,
I muſt entreat you—

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I conceive your mind Sir,
I will not chide her: yet ten duckets Duke,
She falls upon he knees, ten more ſhe dare not—

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I muſt not have her frighted.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Well you ſhall not: Enter Fred. and Peter.
But like a ſummers evening againſt heate,
Marke how I'le guild he cheekes?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: How now.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Ye may Sir:
Not to abuſe your patience, noble friends,
Nor hold ye off with tedious circumſtance,
For you muſt know,—

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Where is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Gone Sir.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: What did you ſay Sir?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Gone, by heaven removed,
The woman of the houſe too.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Well Don Fredrick.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Don Iohn, it is not well, but—

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Gone?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: This fellow
Can teſtifie I lye not.

sp.speaker: Peter
sp.l: Some foure houres after
My Maſter was departed with this Gentleman,
My fellow and my ſelfe, being ſent of buſineſſe,
(As we muſt thinke) of purpoſe—

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Hang theſe circumſtances,
