They appeare like owles, to ill ends.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Now could I eate
The devil in his own broath, I am ſo tortur'd.
Gone?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Gone?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Directly gone, fled, ſhifted: what would you have me ſay?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Well Gentlemen,
Wrong not my good opinion.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: For your Dukedome
I will not be a knave Sir.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: He that is
A rot run in his bloud.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: But harke ye Gentlemen,
Are ye ſure ye had her here, did ye not dreame this.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Have you your noſe Sir?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Then we had her.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Since you are ſo ſhort, beleeve your having her
Shall ſuffer more conſtruction.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Let it ſuffer,
But if I be not cleere of all diſhonour,
Or practice that may taint my reputation,
And ignorant of where this woman is,
Make me your Cities monſter.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I beleeve ye.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: I could lye with a witch now, to be reveng'd
Upon that Raſcall did this.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Only thus much
I would deſire your Grace, for my minde gives me
Before night yet ſhe is yours: ſtop all opinion,
And let no anger out, till full cauſe call it,
Then every mans owne work's to juſtifie him,
And this day let us give to ſearch: my man here
Tels me, by chance he ſaw out of a window
(Which place he has taken note of) ſuch a face
As our old Landladies, he beleeves the ſame too,
And by her hood aſſures it: Let's firſt thether,
For ſhe being found, all's ended.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Come, for heavens ſake,
And Fortune, and thou beeſt not ever turning,
If there be one firme ſtep in all thy reelings,
Now ſettle it, and ſave my hopes: away friends. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: With all my jewels?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: All Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And that money
I left i'th' trunke?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: The Trunke broke, and that gone too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Franſciſco of the plot?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Gone with the wench too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The mighty poxe go with 'em: belike they thought
I was no man of this world, and thoſe trifles
Would but diſturbe my conſcience.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Sure they thought Sir,
You would not live to perſecute 'em.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Whore and Fidler,
Why, what a conſort have they made? Hen and bacon?
Well my ſweet Miſtris, well good Madam martaile?
You that have hung about my neck, and lick't me,
I'le try how handſomely your Ladyſhip
Can hang upon a Gallowes, there's your Maſter-piece;
But harke ye Sirrah, no imagition Bawd ready above.
Of where they ſhould be?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: None Sir, yet we have ſearch'd
All places we ſuſpected; I beleeve Sir,
They have taken towards the Ports.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Get me a conjurer,
One that can raiſe a water devill, I'le port 'em;
Play at duck and drake with my money? take heed Fidler;
I'le dance ye by this hand, your Fidle-ſticke
I'le greaſe of a new faſhion, for preſuming
To medle with my degamboys: get me a Conjurer,
Enquire me out a man that lets out devils:
None but my C. Cliffe ſerve your turne?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I know not—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: In every ſtreet, Tom foole, any bleare-eyd people
With red heads, and flat noſes can performe it;
Thou ſhalt know 'em by their half gowns & no breeches:
Mount my mare Fidler? ha boy? up at firſt daſh?
Sit ſure, I'le clap a nettle, and a ſmart one,
Shall make your filly firck: I will find Fidier,
I'le put you to your plundge boy: Sirrah meet me
Some two houres hence at home; In the meane time
Find out a conjurer and know his price,
How he will let his devils by the day out,
I'le have 'em, and they be above ground. Exit Ant.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Now bleſſe me,
What a mad man is this? I muſt do ſomething
To pleaſe his humour: ſuch a man I'le aske for,
And tell him where he is: but to come neare him,
Or have any thing to do with his don devills,
I thanke my feare, I dare not, nor I will not. Exit.

div.head: Scaene 3.
div.stage: Enter Duke, Petruchio, Fredrick, John, Peter, Servant with bottles.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Whether wilt thou lead us?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: 'Tis hard by ſir.
And ten to one this wine goes thether.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Forward.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Are they growne ſo merry.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: 'Tis moſt likely
She has heard of this good fortune, and determines
To waſh her ſorrowes off.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: 'Tis ſo; that houſe ſir
Is it: out of that window certainly
I ſaw my old Miſtriſſes face.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: They are merry indeed, Muſicke.
Harke I here Muſicke too.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Excellent Muſick.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Would I were ev'n among 'em and alone how,
A pallat for the purpoſe in a corner,
And good rich wine within me; what gay ſport
Could I make in an houre now? Song.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Harke a voice too;
Let's not ſtir yet by any meanes.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Was this her owne voyce?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Yes ſure.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis a rare one. Enter Bawd (above)

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: The Song confirmes her here too: for if ye marke it,
It ſpake of liberty, and free enjoying
The happy end of pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Looke ye there ſir,
Do ye know that head?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis my good Landlady,
I find feare has done all this.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Shee I ſweare,
And now do I know by the hanging of her hood,
She is parcell drunke: ſhall we go in?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Not yet Sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: No, let 'em take their pleaſure,

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: When it is higheſt, Muſicke.
Wee'll ſtep in, and amaze 'em: peace more Muſicke.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: This Muſick murders me; what bloud have I now?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I ſhould know that face. Enter Fran. and Exit.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: By this light 'tis he Fredricks,
That bred our firſt ſuſpitions, the ſame fellow.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: He that we overtooke, and overheard too
Diſcourſing of Conſtantia.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Still the ſame;
Now he ſlips in.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: She muſt be here Sir:
This is the very fellow, I told your Grace Enter Fran.
We found upon the way; and what his talke was.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Why, ſure I know this fellow; yes, 'tis he,
Franciſco, Antonio's Boy, a rare Muſitian,
He taught my Siſter on the Lute, and is ever
(She loves his voice ſo well) about her: certaine,
Without all doubt ſhe is here: it muſt be ſo.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Here? that's no queſtion: what ſhould our hen o'th game elſe
Do here without her? if ſhe be not here
(I am ſo confident) let your Grace beleeve,
We two are arrant Raſcalls, and have abus'd ye.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: I ſay ſo too.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Why there's the hood againe now,
The guard that guides us; I know the fabricke of it.
And know the old tree of that ſaddle yet, 'twas made of
A hunting hood, obſerve it.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Who ſhall enter?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: I'le make one.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: I, another.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: But ſo carry it,
That all her joyes flow not together.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: If we told her,
Your Grace would none of her?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: By no meanes Signior,
'Twould turne her wild, ſtarke frantick.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Or aſſur'd her—

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Nothing of that? ſtarve nature? this ye may ſir.
That the conditions of our feare yet ſtand
On nyce and dangerous knittings: or that a little
I ſeeme to doubt the child.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Would I could draw her
To hate your Grace with theſe things.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Come let's enter, Exit. Pet. and Ioh. Muſick.
And now he ſees me not, I'le ſearch her ſoundly.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Now lucke of all ſides.

sp.speaker: Fred
sp.l: Doubt it not: more Muſicke:
Sure ſhe has heard ſome comfort.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Yes, ſtand ſtill ſir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: This is the maddeſt ſong.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Applyed for certaine Claping of a doore.
To ſome ſtrange mellancholly ſhe is loden with.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Now all the ſport begins—harke?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: They are amongſt'em,
The feares now, and the ſhakings? Trampling above.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Our old Lady
(Harke how they run) is euen now at this inſtant Ceaſe Muſick Petr. and Iohn within.
Ready to looſe her head peice by Don Iohn,
Or creeping through a Cat hole.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Bring 'em downe,
And you ſir, follow me.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Hee's angry with 'em,
I muſt not ſuffer this.
Bowle downe the Bawd there Iohn within.
Old Erra mater: you Lady leachery
For the good will I beare to'th game, moſt tenderly
Shall be lead out, and laſh'd.

div.stage: Enter Petruchio, Iohn, Whore, and Bawd, with Franciſco.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Is this Conſtantia?
Why Gentlemen? what do you meane? is this ſhe?

sp.speaker: Whore
sp.l: I am Conſtantia ſir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: A Whore ye are ſir.

sp.speaker: Whore
sp.l: 'Tis very true: I am a Whore indeed ſir.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: She will not lye yet, though ſhe ſteale.

sp.speaker: Whore
sp.l: A plaine whore,
If you pleaſe to imploy me.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: And an impudent—

sp.speaker: Whore
sp.l: Plaine dealing now is impudence.
One if you will ſir, can ſhew ye as much ſport
In one halfe houre, and with as much variety,
As a far wiſer woman can in halfe a yeare:
For there my way lies.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Is ſhe not drunk too?

sp.speaker: Whore
sp.l: A little guilded o're ſir,
Old ſack, old ſacke boyes.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: This is ſaliant.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: A brave bold queane.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Is this your certainty?
Do ye know the man ye wrong thus, Gentlemen?
Is this the woman meant?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: That your Landlady?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: I know not what to ſay.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Am I a perſon
To be your ſport Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: I do beleeve now certaine
I am a knave; but how, or when—

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What are you?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Bawd to this peece of pye meat.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.l: A poore Gentlewoman
That lyes in Towne, about Law buſineſſe,
And't like your worſhips.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: You ſhall have Law, beleeve it.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.l: I'le ſhew your maſterſhip my caſe.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: By no meanes,
I had rather ſee a Cuſtard.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.l: My dead husband
Left it even thus ſir.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Bleſſe mine eyes from blaſting,
I was never ſo frighted with a caſe.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.l: And ſo ſir—

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Enough, put up good velvet head.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What are you two now,
By your owne free confeſſions?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: What you ſhall thinke us,
Though to my ſelfe I am certaine, and my life
Shall make that good and perfect, or fall with it.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: We are ſure of nothing (Fred) that's the truth on't:
I do not think my nam's Don John, nor dare not
Beleeve any thing that concernes me, but my debts,
Nor thoſe in way of payment: things are ſo carried,
What to entreat your Grace, or how to tell ye
We are, or we are not, is paſt my cunning,
But I would faine imagine we are honoſt,
And o' my conſcience, I ſhould fight in't—

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Thus then,
For we may be all abus'd.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: 'Tis poſſible,
For how ſhould this concerne them?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Here let's part—
Untill to morrow this time: we to our way,
To make this doubt out, and you to your way;
Pawning our honours then to meet againe,
When if ſhe be not found.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: We ſtand engaged
To anſwer any worthy way we are cald to.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: We aske no more.

sp.speaker: Whore
sp.l: Ye have done with us then?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: No Dame.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: But is her name Conſtantia?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Yes a moveable
Belonging to a friend of mine: come out Fidler,
What ſay you to this Lady; be not fearfull?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Saving the reverence of my Maſters pleaſure,
I ſay ſhe is a whore, and that ſhe has robb'd him,
Hoping his hurts would kill him.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.l: Who provok't me?
Nay ſirrah ſqueak, Ile ſee your treble ſtrings
Ty'd up too; if I hang, Ile ſpoyle your piping,
Your ſweet face ſhall not ſave yee.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Thou dam'd impudence,
And thou dry'd devill; where's the Officer?

sp.speaker: Peter
sp.l: Hee's here ſir. Enter Officer.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Lodge theſe ſafe till I ſend for 'em;
Let none come to 'em, nor no noiſe be heard
Of where they are, or why: away.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: By this hand
A handſome whore: Now will I be arreſted,
And brought home to this officers: a ſtout whore,
I love ſuch ſtirring ware: pox o' this buſineſſe,
A man muſt haunt out morſells for another,
And ſtarve himſelf: a quick-ey'd whore, that's wild-fire,
And makes the bloud dance through the veines like bil|lowes.
I will reprive this whore.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Well, good luck with ye.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: As much attend your Grace.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: To morrow certaine—

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: If we out-live this night ſir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Come Don John,
We have ſomething now to doe.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: I am ſure I would have.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: If ſhe be not found, we muſt fight.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: I am glad on't,
I have not fought a great while.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: If we dye—

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Ther's ſo much money ſav'd in lecherie. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Duke, Petruchio below, and Vechio above.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: IT ſhould be here abouts.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Your grace is right,
This is the houſe I know it.

sp.speaker: Voch.
sp.l: Grace?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: 'Tis further
By the deſcription we received.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Good my Lord the Duke,
Believe me, for I know it certainly,
This is the very houſe.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: My Lord the Duke?

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Pray heaven this man Prove right now.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Beleeve it, hee's a moſt ſufficient Scholler,
And can doe rare tricks this way; for a figure,
Or raiſing an appearance, whole Chriſtendome
Has not a better; I have heard ſtrange wonders of him.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: But can he ſhew us where ſhe is?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Moſt certaine,
And for what cauſe too ſhe departed.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Knock then,
For I am great with expectation,
Till this man ſatisfie me: I feare the Spaniards,
Yet they appeare brave fellowes: can he tell us?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: With a wet finger, whether they be falſe.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Away then.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Who's within here? Enter Vechio.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Your Grace may enter.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: How can he know me?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: He knowes all.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: And you ſir. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: What do you call his name?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Why, Peter Vechio.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: They ſay he can raiſe devills,
Can he make 'em
Tell truth too, when he has raiſ'd 'em? for beleeve it,
Theſe devils are the lyingſt Raſcalls.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: He can compell 'em.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: With what? can he
Tye ſquibs in their tailes, and fire the truth out?
Or make 'em eate a bawling Puritan,
Whoſe ſanctified zeale ſhall rumble like an Earthquake?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: With Spels man?

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: I with ſpoones as ſoone, doſt thou thinke
The devill ſuch an Aſſe as people make him?
Such a poore coxcomb? ſuch a penny foot poſt?
Compel'd with croſſe and pile to run of errands?
With Aſteroth, and Behemoth, and Belfagor?
Why ſhould he ſhake at ſounds, that lives in a ſmiths forg?
Or if he do—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Without all doubt he do's Iohn.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Why ſhould not Bilbo raiſe him, or a paire of bullyons,
They go as big as any? or an unſhod Car,
When he goes tumble, tumble o're the ſtones,
Like Anacreons drunken verſes, make us tremble?
Theſe make as fell a noyſe; me thinkes the collick
Well handled, and fed with ſmall beere—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Tis the vertue—

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: The vertue? nay, and goodneſſe fetch him up once,
Has loſt a friend of me; the wiſe old Gentleman
Knowes when, and how; I'le lay this hand to two pence,
Let all tho Conjurers in Chriſtendome,
With all their ſpells, and vertues call upon him,
And I but thinke upon a wench, and follow it,
He ſhall be ſooner mine then theirs; where's vertue?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Thou art the moſt ſufficient, (I'le ſay for thee)
Not to beleeve a thing —

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: O ſir, ſlow credit
Is the beſt child of knowledge; I'le go with ye,
And if he can do any thing, I'le thinke
As you would have me.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Let's enquire a long,
For certaine we are not far off.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Nor much nearer. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaene 3.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: You loſt her yeſternight.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: How thinke you ſir?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Is your name Vechio?

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Yes ſir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: And you can ſhew me
Theſe; things you promiſe.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Your graces word bound to me,
No hand of Law ſhall ſeize me.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: As I live ſir—

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: And as I live, that can do ſomething too ſir.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: I take your promiſes: ſtay here a little,
Till I prepare ſome Ceremonies, and I'le ſatisfie ye.
The Ladies name's Conſtantia?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Yes

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: I come ſtraight. Exit Vech.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Sure hee's a learned man.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: The moſt now living;
Did your grace marke when we told all theſe circumſtances,
How ever and anon he bolted from us
To uſe his ſtudies helpe?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Now I thinke rather
To talke with ſome familiar.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Not unlikely,
For ſure he has 'em ſubject.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: How could he elſe
Tell when ſhe went, and who went with her?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: True.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Or hit upon mine honour: or aſſure me
The Lady lov'd me dearely?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: 'Twas ſo.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Now,
I do beſeech your Grace ſit downe, and you ſir;
Nay pray ſit cloſe like brothers.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: A rare fellow.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: And what ye ſee, ſtir not at, nor uſe a word,
Untill I aske ye; for what ſhall appeare
Is but weake apparition and thin ayre
Not to be held, nor ſpoken too. Knocking within.

div.stage: John, Frederick, and a Servant within.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: We are counſelled—

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: What noiſe is that without there?

sp.speaker: Fred. Within.
sp.l: We muſt ſpeake with him.

sp.speaker: Ser. Within.
sp.l: Hee's buſie Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Iohn. Within.
sp.l: That's all one friend,
We muſt, and will ſpeake with him.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Let 'em in ſir,
We know their tongues and buſineſſe, 'tis our owne,
And in this very cauſe that we now come for,
They alſo come to be inſtructed.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Let 'em in then:
Sit down, I know your meaning.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: The Duke before us,
Now we ſhall ſure know ſomething.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Not a queſtion,
But make your eyes, your tongues—

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: This is a ſtrange jugler,
Neither indent before hand for his payment,
Nor know the breadth of the buſineſſe; ſure his devell
Comes out of Lapland were they ſell men winds,
For dead drinke, and old doublets.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Peace, he conjures.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Let him, he cannot raiſe my devill.

sp.speaker: Fred,
sp.l: Prethee peace.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Appeare, appeare,
And you ſoft winds ſo cleare,
That dance upon the leaves, and make them ſing
Gentle love-layes to the Spring,
Gilding all the vales below
With your verdure as ye blow,
Raiſe theſe formes from under ground
With a ſoft and happy ſound. Soft Muſick.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: This is an honeſt Conjurer, and a pretty Poet;
I like his words well, there's no bumbaſt in 'em,
But do you thinke now, he can cudgell up the devill,
With this ſhort ſtaffe of Verſes?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Peace the ſpirits— 2. Shapes of women paſſe by.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Nay, and they be no worſe—

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Do ye know theſe faces?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Sit ſtill upon your lives then: and marke what follows:
Away, away.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Theſe devils do not paint ſure?
Have they no ſweeter ſhapes in hell? Conſtantia paſſes by.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Harke now Iohn.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: I marry, this moves ſomething like, this devill
Carries ſome metall in her gate.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: I find ye,
You would ſee her face unvail'd?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Be uncovered.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: O heaven!

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Peace.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: See how ſhe bluſhes.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: This devill for my money; this is ſhe Boy,
Why thou ſhake? I burne.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Sit ſtill, and ſilent.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: She lookes back at me; now ſhe ſmiles ſir.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Silence.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I muſt riſe, or burſt. Exit. Conſt.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Ye ſee what followes—

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: O gentle ſir this ſhape agen.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: I cannot,
'Tis all diſolv'd againe: this was the figure.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: The very ſame ſir.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: No hope once more to ſee it?

sp.speaker: Ve.
sp.l: You might have kept it longer, had ye ſpar'd it,
Now 'tis impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: No meanes to find it?

sp.speaker: Ve.
sp.l: Yes that there is: ſit ſtill a while, there's wine
To thaw the wonder from your hearts: drinke well ſir.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: This Conjurer is a right good fellow too,
A lad of mettle; two ſuch devils more
Would make me a Conjurer: what wine is it?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Hollock.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: The devil's in it then, looke how it dances?
Well, if I be—

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: We are all before ye,
That's your beſt comfort ſir.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Byth' mas brave wine;
Nay, and the Devils live in this hell, I dare venture
Within theſe two months yet to be delivered
Of a large legion of 'em. Enter Vechio.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Here 'a comes,
Silence of all ſides Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Vec.
sp.l: Good your grace,
Obſerve a ſtricter temper, and you too gallants,
You'l be deluded all elſe. This merry devill
That next appeares, for ſuch a one you'l find it,
Muſt be cal'd up by a ſtrange incantation,
A Song, and I muſt ſing it: pray beare with me,
And pardon my rude pipe; for yet ere parting
Twenty to one I pleaſe ye.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: We are arm'd Sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Nor ſhall you ſee us more tranſgreſſe.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: What think'ſt thou
Now Iohn?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Why, now do I thinke Fredrick,
(And it I thinke amiſſe heaven pardon me,)
This honeſt Conjurer, with ſome foure or five
Of his good fellow devils, and my ſelfe,
Shall be yet drunke ere midnight. Song.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Peace, he conjures.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Why, this is the Song Fredrick: twenty pound now
To ſee but our Don Gillian.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Peace it appeares.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: I cannot peace: devils in French hoods Fredrick?
Sathans old Siringes?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What's this?

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Peace.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: She, Boy.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: What doſt thou meane?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: She, Boy, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: She, boy.
The very child too Fredrick;

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: She laughes on us
Aloud Iohn, has the devill theſe affections?
I do beleeve 'tis ſhe indeed.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Stand ſtill.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: I will not;
Who calls Jeronimo from his naked bed?
Sweet Lady, was it you? If thou beeſt the devill,
Firſt, having croſt my ſelfe, to keep out wildfire,
Then ſaid ſome ſpeciall prayers to defend me
Againſt thy moſt unhallowed hood: have at thee.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Hold ſir, I am no devill.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: That's all one.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: I am your very Landlady.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: I defie thee:
Thus as St. Dunſtan blew the devils noſe
With a paire of tongs, even ſo right worſhipfull—

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Sweet ſon, I am old Gillion.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: This is no ſpirit.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Art thou old Gillian, fleſh and bone?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: I am Son.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.p: Sit ſtill ſir, now I'le ſhew you all. Ex. Vech.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Where's thy bottle?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Here, I beſeech ye ſon—

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: For I know the devill
Cannot aſſume that ſhape.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Tis ſhe Iohn, certaine—

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: A hogs poxe o'your mouldy chaps, what make you
Tumbling and juggling here?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: I am quit now Signior,
For all the prankes you plaid, and railings at me,
For to tell true, out of a trick I put
Upon your high behaviours, which was a lye,
But then it ſerv'd my turne, I drew the Lady
Unto my kinſmans here, only to torture
Your Don-ſhips for a day or two; and ſecure her
Out of all thoughts of danger: here ſhe comes now.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: May I yet ſpeake?

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Yes, and embrace her too,
For one that loves you deerer—

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: O my ſweeteſt.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Bluſh not, I will not chide ye.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: To add more
Unto the joy I know, I bring ye, ſee ſir,
The happy fruit of all our vowes.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Heavens bleſſing
Be round about thee ever.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Pray bleſſe me to,
For if your grace be well inſtructed this way,
You'l find the keeping halfe the getting.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: How ſir?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: I'le tell ye that anon.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: 'Tis true this Gentleman
'Has done a charity worthy your favour,
And let him have it deare ſir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: My beſt Lady
She has, and ever ſhall have: ſo muſt you ſir,
To whom I am equall bound, as to my being.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Your Graces humble ſervants—

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Why kneele you ſir?

sp.speaker: Ve.
sp.l: For pardon for my boldneſſe: yet 'twas harmleſſe
And all the art I have ſir; thoſe your grace ſaw
Which you thought ſpirits, were my neighbours children
Whom I inſtruct in Grammer, here, and Muſick;
Their ſhapes, the peoples fond opinions,
Beleeving I can conjure, and oft repairing
To know of things ſtolne from 'em, I keepe about me,
And alwaies have in readineſſe; by conjecture
Out of their owne confeſſions, I oft tell 'em
Things, that by chance have fallen out ſo: which way
(Having the perſons here, I knew you ſought for)
I wrought upon your grace: my end is mirth,
And pleaſing, if I can, all parties.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I beleeve it,
For you have pleas'd me truly: ſo well pleas'd me,
That when I ſhall forget it—

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Here's old Antonio,
I ſpide him at a window, comming mainely
I know about his whore, the man you light on,
As yon diſcovered unto me: good your Grace,
Let's ſtand by all, 'twill be a mirth above all,
To obſerve his pelting fury.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: About a wench ſir?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: A young whore that has rob'd him,

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: But do you know ſir,
Where ſhe is?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Yes, and will make that perfect—

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: I am inſtructed well then.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: If he come
To have a devill ſhew'd him, by all meanes
Let me be he, I can rore rarely.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Be ſo,
But take heed to his anger.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Slip in quickly,
There you ſhall find ſuites of all ſorts: when I call,
Be ready and come forward. Ex. all but Vech.
Who's there come in?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Are you the Conjurer?

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Sir I can do a little
That way, if you pleaſe to imploy me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Preſently ſhew me a devill that can tell—

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Where your wench is.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You are i'th'right; as alſo where the Fidler
That was conſenting to her.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Sit ye there ſir,
Ye ſhall know preſently: can ye pray heartily?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why, is your devill ſo furious?

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: I muſt ſhew ye
A forme, may chance affright ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: He muſt fart fire then:
Take you no care for me.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Aſcend Aſterth, Enter Don John like a Spirit.
Why, when, appeare I ſay—Now queſtion him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Where is my whore Don devill?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Gone to China,
To be the great Chams Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: That's a lye devill:
Where are my jewels?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Pawn'd for Peticoates.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: That may be; where's the Fidler?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Condemn'd to th' Gallowes,
For robbing of a Mill.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The lyingſt devill
That e're I dealt withall, and the unlikelieſt:
What was that Raſcall hurt me?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Who was he?

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Do ye here conjurer,
Dare you venture your devill?

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Then I'le venture my dagger;
Have at your devils pate; do ye mew? Enter all.

sp.speaker: Vech.
sp.l: Hold.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Hold there,
I do command ye hold.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Is this the devill?
Why Conjurer—

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: 'Has been a devill to you ſir.
But now you ſhall forget all: your whores ſafe,
And all your Jewels: your Boy too.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Now the devill indeed
Lay his ten claws upon thee, for my pate
Finds what it is to be a fend.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: All ſafe?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Pray ye know this perſon: all's right now.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Your grace
May now command me then: but where's my whore?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Ready to goe to whiping.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My whore whipt?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Yes, your whore without doubt Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Whipt? pray Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Why, would you have her once more rob ye? the young boy
You may forgive, he was intic'd.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: The Whore ſir,
Would rather carry pitty: a hanſome Whore.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A Gentleman I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Let's in all.
And if we ſee contrition in your whore ſir,
Much may be done.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Now my deare faire, to you,
And the full conſummation of my Vow.

div.head: Prologue.
div.l: APtneſſe for mirth to all, this inſtant night
Thalia hath prepar'd for your delight,
Her choice and curious Viands, in each part,
Seaſon'd with rarities of wit, as Art;
Nor feare I to be tax'd for a vaine boaſt,
My promiſe will finde credit with the moſt,
When they know Ingenuous Fletcher made it, hee
Being in himſelfe a perfect Comedie.
And ſome ſit here, I doubt not dare a verre,
Living he made that houſe a Theater
Which he pleas'd to frequent; and thus much we
Could not but pay to his loud memorie.
For our ſelves we doe entreat that you would not
Expect ſtrange turnes, and windings in the Plot,
Objects of State, and now and then a Rhime,
To gall particular perſons, with the time;
Or that his to wring Muſe hath made her flight
Nearer your apprehenſion then your ſight:
But if that ſweet expreſsions, quick conceit,
Familiar language, faſhion'd to the weight
Of ſuch as ſpeake it, have the power to raiſe
Your grace to us, with Trophies to his praiſe:
We may profeſſe, preſuming on his skill,
If his Chances pleaſe not you, our fortune's ill.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: VVE have not held you long, nor doe I ſee
One brow in this ſelected company
Aſſuring a diſlike, our paines were eas'd.
Could we be confident that all riſe pleas'd:
But ſuch ambition ſoares too high: If wee
Have ſatisfi'd the beſt, and they agree
In a faire cenſure, We have our reward;
And in them arm'd, deſire no ſurer guard.
